block.p: In her essay in The New Yorker, Arlene Croce did not give the impression that she objected to such images as, say, Piero della Francesca's "Flagellation of Christ" or Leon Golub's transfixing scenes of torture in his "Gigantomachy" series. The implication of her argument is that the essence of a work of art is its expressive power, which is conveyed by its tone: some paintings whine, others sing without vibrato the universal human experience of suffering. IRMA B. JAFFE New York
